Since the strong earthquake in Turkey and Syria, rescue teams from several dozen countries have been working tirelessly in the rubble of thousands of buildings, searching for survivors buried under debris.
In the cold, they often call for silence, because they are trying to hear any signs of life from the crumbling concrete piles.
According to Reuters, two women survived for several days in the rubble of the earthquake and were rescued.
However, the death toll from the earthquake has risen to 24,150 people.
Turkey's death toll is 20,665 people, and the death toll in Syria is over 3,500.

The earthquake that occurred on Monday was a magnitude 7.8 quake, which continued to cause strong aftershocks in Turkey and Syria, and was the seventh most deadly natural disaster of the century, surpassing the 2011 earthquake and tsunami in Japan and coming close to the 31,000 deaths caused by the 2003 earthquake in neighboring Iran.

Turkish authorities stated on Saturday that two women were trapped for 122 hours after the deadliest earthquake in the region in 20 years, and rescuers in Turkey were able to save the two women from the rubble of collapsed buildings.
The other injured man, 55-year-old Masallah Cicek, was rescued from the rubble of a collapsed building in the city of Diyarbakir in southeastern Turkey.
In the cold temperature, rescuers often call for quietness because they try their best to hear any life sound from the piles of old concrete.

In the Samandag district of Turkey, rescue workers crouched on the concrete slabs and whispered "Inshallah"—"God protect"—as they gingerly extended their hands into the rubble to rescue a newborn baby who was 10 days old.
He opened his eyes wide and Yagiz Ulas was wrapped in a warm blanket and taken to a field hospital.
Video images show that emergency personnel also took his mother away; she was dizzy and pale but conscious.
Turkey's Vice President Fuat Oktay informed reporters that in the past 24 hours, 67 people were rescued from the rubble, and a total of 31,000 rescue personnel were mobilized in the affected areas.
He said that about 80,000 people are receiving treatment in hospital, while 10.5 million people are homeless due to the earthquake and are living in temporary shelters.
As the winter cold conditions cause a lack of food for many people, the people's doubts about the responses of the leaders of the two countries to the rescue operations are growing.

According to Syrian official media, President Bashar al-Assad and his wife Asma visited a hospital in Aleppo, a city that was hit by an earthquake, and this was the first time they had visited a disaster-stricken area since the earthquake.
Earlier, the World Food Programme indicated that due to the complexities of relief work in a war zone, its stocks in the northwestern part of Syria controlled by the rebels were about to run out.
On Friday, Erdogan visited the Adıyaman province of Turkey and acknowledged that the government's response had not been as fast as expected.
Opponents have seized on this issue to attack Erdogan, who is running for re-election in the vote on May 14th, but the vote may be delayed due to the disaster.
Reuters states that anger at delaying aid and initiating rescue operations may affect the election.
Even before the earthquake, voting was considered the most serious challenge that Erdogan had faced in the twenty years since he took office.
Al-Din called for unity and denounced what he called "the negative activities for political interests."
Critics say, "The earthquake was big, but the real problem is the lack of coordination, the lack of planning, and the incompetence."

VNA Hanoi - VNA correspondents report that on the morning of February 11 during a visit to Brunei Darussalam, Prime Minister Phạm Minh Chính and his wife visited the University of Brunei Darussalam (UBD, also known as "Brunei University").
Universiti Teknologi Malaysia is the largest higher education and scientific research center in Brunei, and ranks third in the regional university rankings.
The University of Brunei Darussalam officially established a partnership with Vietnam's FPT University in July 2013, with the main area of cooperation being English language training.
In addition to English, French, German, Japanese, and Korean, Vietnamese is also taught at the University of Brunei Darussalam.
When visiting Brunei University, Prime Minister Pham Minh Chinh and his wife exchanged greetings with students in the Vietnamese language class.

Prime Minister Pham Minh Chinh is happy to see more and more foreigners learning Vietnamese, which in turn motivates him to contribute to promoting the Vietnamese culture and local customs to the world.

Prime Minister Phạm Minh Chính expressed the belief that the Vietnamese teaching team at Universiti Teknologi Brunei Darussalam would continue to grow in strength; that students in the Vietnamese class would become more interested in the Vietnamese language, and would strive to become fluent in it as soon as possible, and would become ambassadors for the friendly relations between the two countries based on the Vietnamese language.

While this is a good opportunity, Pham Minh Chinh Prime Minister also exchanged with the Vietnamese students studying English at the FPT-UBD Global Center in Danang via video conference to understand their situation, especially during the pandemic.

Prime Minister Phạm Minh Chính believes that the cooperation between FPT University in Vietnam and Brunei University is particularly symbolic of the vibrant education cooperation between Vietnam and Brunei.

At the same time, we hope that the students of this center will make greater progress in their studies, and make positive contributions to the development of the friendly cooperative relationship between Vietnam and the two countries.

Prime Minister Pham Minh Chinh highly praised the achievements of cooperation in education between Brunei and the Ministry of Education of Brunei during his discussions with the Minister of Education of Brunei and the leaders of the universities of Brunei, including the cooperation between FPT University and the University of Brunei, and the decision of the University of Brunei to include Vietnamese in its teaching curriculum.

Prime Minister Phạm Minh Chính hopes that Vietnam University will continue to pay attention to ensuring the quality of Vietnamese language instruction and further expand the size of the Vietnamese language class.

Vietnam's Prime Minister Phạm Minh Chính highly praised the positive results achieved by the two countries in cooperation on the basis of the education cooperation memorandum of understanding signed in April 2014; he suggested that Brunei should continue to provide more scholarships and effectively implement short-term exchange training projects, such as the Global Discovery Programme and the Discovery Year.

Prime Minister Phạm Minh Chính highly praised the establishment of the first branch of the University of Brunei in Vietnam, and the further expansion of cooperation with Vietnamese higher education institutions; he also believes that the development scale of the University of Brunei in the region and worldwide is growing ever stronger.
Prime Minister Pham Minh Chinh wishes that VGU will continue to develop and contribute more and more to the education sector of Brunei, and also to the education and training institutions in Vietnam.

VNA Hanoi—VNA Hanoi special correspondent Hoai Thanh reports that the visit of Prime Minister Pham Binh Minh and his wife to Singapore and Brunei has been successfully completed, and has resulted in comprehensive, concrete, and practical results.
In his three days in Singapore and Brunei, Pham Minh Chinh Prime Minister attended more than 30 different events.

The achievements have contributed to the further development of the strategic partnership between Vietnam and New Zealand and the comprehensive partnership between Vietnam and Vietnamese as well as the deepening, broadening and effective development of the two countries' strategic partnership.

During his visit to the two countries, Prime Minister Pham Minh Chinh continued to reiterate the foreign policy of the Vietnamese Party and State, which is independent, multi-cultural, multi-faceted, and wishes to be a good friend and reliable partner to all countries, and a responsible member of the international community.
Strengthening relations with Singapore and Brunei is a need for each country, and a focus on the well-being of their own people, and on peace, stability, and development for the region and the world.

At the various meetings and talks, Prime Minister Pham Minh Chinh and the leaders of Singapore and Brunei agreed that bilateral cooperation between the two countries should be further strengthened through frequent visits by high-level delegations, effective implementation of the various bilateral cooperation mechanisms, and the signing of important cooperation agreements.
Many agreements were signed during this visit.

Among the highlights are the Memorandum of Understanding signed with Singapore on green and digital economy partnerships and the Action Plan signed with Brunei for strengthening comprehensive partnerships from 2023 to 2027.
Vietnam and Singapore signed the "Memorandum of Understanding on Green and Digital Economy Partnership".

In meetings with business leaders, panel discussions, or during economic forums, Phạm Minh Chính Prime Minister emphasized that Vietnam welcomes the expansion of investment in digital transformation, green energy, high-tech, and innovative and creative fields, and is creating favorable conditions for such investments.

This visit not only helps to deepen the cooperation between Vietnam, Singapore, and Brunei in traditional fields such as politics, diplomacy, economy, security, defense, education-training, oil and gas, tourism, and civilian exchanges, but also creates a framework for cooperation in potential new fields such as digital economy, green economy, energy transformation, innovation and creativity, smart cities, and sustainable development.
Sultan Hassanal Bolkiah, the ruler of Brunei, and Prime Minister Phạm Minh Chính are preparing to enter a bilateral meeting.
During his visit to the two countries, Phạm Minh Chính Prime Minister arranged time to visit and listen to the thoughts and wishes of the Vietnamese community living in the area.

During the meeting between the heads of state, Pham Minh Chinh Prime Minister suggested that both countries' authorities should pay more attention to the fair treatment of the local Vietnamese community and create favorable conditions for the local Vietnamese community to contribute to the development of the local society and cultivate the relationship between the two countries.
Both suggestions were approved and supported by the leaders of both countries.

Special attention should be paid to the fact that Phạm Minh Chính Prime Minister shared with the leaders of the two countries the desire to build a united, peaceful, stable and prosperous ASEAN Community; and agreed to maintain close cooperation with ASEAN countries and enhance ASEAN's central role in the context of a complex and volatile regional and international situation.

With the important achievements obtained, Pham Minh Chinh Prime Minister's official visit to Singapore and Brunei as part of the priority to strengthen relations with neighboring countries in the East Asian region, as well as the implementation of the 12th Resolution of the Politburo on Vietnamese Overseas Affairs in the new situation (12-KLW) has made a positive contribution to the unification of the whole nation.

The tone of this book is extremely flat, like that of plain water. The words and phrases are extremely minimalistic, and the plot is very quiet and calm, like a street in the afternoon in the summertime.

Appreciate you, and want you to know it!
The first factor determining job satisfaction is not the salary, but whether the person is sufficiently valued and appreciated in their work.
According to Maslow’s Hierarchy, once a person’s basic survival needs are met, the most urgent need is for psychological needs to be met—the need to be understood, recognized, and appreciated.
The author describes five languages of affirmation in this book: words of affirmation, quality time, acts of service, receiving gifts, and physical touch.

What is important is not that you know what the five languages of appreciation are, but that you can use these five languages of appreciation from the bottom of your heart to express your gratitude to those around you, whether they are family members, friends, or co-workers.
In fact, the more intimate the relationship, the more we need to praise and thank each other, which will make our lives more beautiful.
Learning to praise can also help retain talent to a certain extent, thereby reducing the rate of resignations.
